We use JUnit for both unit tests and some level of integration tests. We can have a side discussion on the merits of that, but it's a fact. We have right now around 60 developers working across 10 projects. All 10 projects share a common architecture and supporting components. I'd guess we have around 7000 unit tests across the 10 projects. Our coverage is a bit lacking but I know it's helped.
 
Here are 2 situations where we'd use this:
 
 
Situation 1:
Some of our tests acquire information from external systems we do not have control over. Those systems sometimes go through maintenance for a day or two or sometimes those systems clear out all of the test data and repopulate (I hate that we cannot own a part of the test data, but it's been a political issue for 3 years). When this happens, we need to update tests. It usually takes a 1 to 3 days to do that - often the information the test uses is externalized, we still have to find appropriate replacement keys. So we don't actually update the test, we update the data driven part of the tests. While that happens, other development would lose out on CI or we'd have to disable those tests. It'd be nice to just put a 3-day delay on them. Then they'd start running again automatically. So I guess the ignore is until a date and after that the test continues to run.

Situation 2:
I'm working on something in the trunk. I want to write tests and check in my work. I could work in a branch, check in all I want and then make sure to merge that branch back into the trunk. However, if I do that, I have to keep the branch up to date with the trunk and vice versa - merging in both directions. This is a pain. So I'd rather just write several tests. Put on the ignore, check them in. Then take out the ignore while I continue my development (better yet, maybe I could set some environment variable when executing tests to ignore the ignore!-).
 
We have a utility class called TimeBomb (we're still using JUnit 3.8.1). When we want to disable a test, we put a time bomb in the test. That test will eventually start to ACTIVELY fail in the near future. Here's an example from something else I'm working on, on the side: http://schuchert.wikispaces.com/JUnit+4.x#TimeBomb

I think that would address my concern that @ignore can be forgotten.
A failing test would be a really nice reminder: "ignore expired: <your
message>"
I have not yet used ignore I have not seen the need, when do you typically
need it?

On 6/8/06, Brett L. Schuchert <schuchert@yahoo. com> wrote:
>
> I've been working with a group for the past 3.5 years and we've been
> using JUnit from the beginning. A while back, as the project grew,
> there were times when we would break tests (or because we had
> external dependencies that we had to wait and had not yet mocked
> things out), tests would fail for a few days before we could get to
> them.
>
> This stopped our CI, so we introduced a helper class, TimeBomb. We'd
> add a call to TimeBomb with a date and the test would stop failing
> until after the provided date.
>
> It was an active way to remind us go back and fix something in a few
> days.
>
> @Ignore has a message. What about adding a date? Ignore until the
> date, after which the test will fail by throwing a runtime exception?
>
> Is that crazy?
>
> Brett
